message: Thanwya amma graduate here, will be attending Ain Shams University (hopefully), I'd like your opinion on website/s from which I could self study programming languages, there's corsera, khan academy, coder and code. If there are better ones, kindly drop them in a comment down below. Also I'd like to ask if we're taking c++ in the first semester (for example) should I pre-study c++ or go for another programming language instead? Thanks in advance!

data.message:
Hi, I'm a student at Ain Shams University, Faculty of Engineering. I will major in Computer Engineering. In your first year, you will study 'Computer Technology' in the first semester, it will include a portion about the C programming language. I suggest you learn JavaScript of any other 'scripting language' first as they will not be very intimidating to learn. You can find a very good JavaScript interactive course at Codecademy.com. If you have the time, learn HTML, CSS & JavaScript all together (all from Codecademy). 
If you want to learn C/C++, I suggest learning C from the book written by the founders of C, it is called 'The C Programming Language' by K&R. for C++ I suggest waiting till you grasp C first at college then proceed to learn it. 
Good Luck!
Of course, there are tons of resources to learn from and while that might be good but it also quite overwhelming. So try to focus one source for now so you don't get distracted.

I'll actually be attending as a CS student not a computer engineer but we're on the same page since we're talking about programming, i'll be taking a java course starting next week, i was wondering if i should take JS or C along with java or just focus on it for the time being, what do you suggest?

If you are going to start with Java in college, don't learn C/C++ now, it will just confuse you at first and we don't want that to happen. 
Try Codecademy and JavaScript first to get to learn what is a programming language and how to use it. Beware, Java and JavaScript are completely different in functionality (Java is not JavaScript and vice versa). 
When you proceed with your Java course at college, you can then start to learn C/C++, they share a quite large amount of similarities.
The most important thing to know is that you DON'T have to know every little detail about a programming language in order to master it. Actually caring about those small details might be overwhelming and prevent you from mastering it. Eventually, you will know about them, just do not rush things or try to learn everything at once.

Yes i'm well aware of the difference between Java and JavaScript, I'm not quite sure when will I be taking Java in college but I'm taking courses to get a head start. I guess I'll be taking JavaScript along with Java, might get the hang of it before college starts (that's in two months). Is there anything else I could add to the list?
You may study Java in  CS in Ainshams, but only in OOP course in the 2nd term in the 2nd year
You should join ACM btw

The basics of Java and javascript are quite the same. Javascript is made to be used inside a web browser to be used in DOM (Document Object Manipulation), long story short it is used with HTML and CSS. So for now try to learn Java and that's enough.
I don't know much about ACM, could you elaborate?
I suppose I could do that, thanks a lot Samuel A. Wilson!
Abdelrahman: Anytime, and if you got stuck in something while learning, you are free to ask here!
Abdelrahman Mounir http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CgJnyfYkonU
I sure will make the most out of your experience as well as the others'
I'm glad to help!

If there's anything that has helped me dive deep in CS it was CS50, take that course for god's sake it will help you on the long run.
Also the instructor is an absolute genius and the problem sets are fun.

AbdulRahman Mahmoud Sounds really interesting! I'm really REALLY into problem solving and i'm sure it'll be the same as soon as I join college, I'll make sure to join ACM as soon as the word comes out!
Can I find it on codeacademy as well? عمر عصام
I guess you will find it on eDX or Coursera
Is it easy enough to learn along with Java?

Cs50.edx.org
Give it a try
عمر can tell you
Alright, I'll give it a try, thanks!
The guy explains programming fundamentals in C, it's no big deal to transition from C to C++, Also Java is not that different, for me it was a couple of weeks for the transitions.
I'm fresh out of thanwya amma so I have no knowledge in either C or C++, I'll be starting Java next week. Should I still give it a go or wait after I'm done with the Java course?

If you'd take my opinion I'd advise you to delay learning Java until you have a better grip on programming.
Java is Object Oriented
While C is Procedural
Procedural is simpler to start with.
But if you have to start Java then it's okay you can do both in parallel
